title: Hospital Linen Supply and Waste Collection
content: Hospitals across a region require fresh linen deliveries and the simultaneous pickup of soiled linens for processing. The goal is to minimize total route distance while ensuring no truck exceeds its capacity during either delivery or pickup phases. Routes end at the last stop, as drivers may transfer soiled linens to local processing centers directly.

title: IT Equipment Deployment and Recycling for Remote Offices
content: A multinational tech firm manages IT infrastructure across regional depots (<loc_depot>). Each depot dispatches trucks (capacity `<capacity>`) to deliver new servers and peripherals (linehaul `<demand_linehaul>`) to remote offices, followed by collecting outdated equipment (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`) for recycling. Offices mandate service within strict maintenance windows (<time_windows>), requiring technicians to arrive precisely when staff are available. Routes must originate from the nearest depot and terminate at the final customer site (open routes), ensuring no backhaul pickups occur until all deliveries are complete.

title: Medical Imaging Equipment Maintenance and Parts Recycling
content: Hospital networks rely on mobile technicians to service MRI/CT machines. Vehicles depart from medical supply depots (<loc_depot>) carrying replacement parts (linehaul `<demand_linehaul>`), then collect obsolete components (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`) for hazardous disposal. Each hospital specifies a narrow time window (<time_windows>) when machines can be offline for maintenance. Routes must originate and end at depots only if returning, but most conclude at the last serviced hospital (open routes), prioritizing capacity limits (`<capacity>`) to avoid overloading trucks with bulky equipment.

title: Automated Vending Machine Stocking and Empty Container Retrieval
content: A snack company operates vending machines in high-traffic areas (<loc_customer>). Delivery trucks (<capacity>) from regional warehouses (<loc_depot>) must first refill machines with snacks (linehaul `<demand_linehaul>`) and then collect empty packaging bins (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`). Each machine’s access is restricted to off-peak hours (<time_windows>), and routes must end at the final stop (open routes). Trucks must prioritize deliveries before pickups to prevent contamination of fresh stock with returned containers.

title: E-Waste Collection and Electronics Delivery Network
content: An eco-conscious retailer delivers new smartphones and laptops (linehaul `<demand_linehaul>`) while collecting customers’ old devices (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`) for recycling. Customers schedule pickups/deliveries within specific time windows (<time_windows>), and deliveries must precede pickups to ensure trucks aren’t overloaded with both outbound/inbound cargo. Vehicles depart from multiple regional hubs (<loc_depot>), operate within capacity limits (`<capacity>`), and finalize routes at the last customer (open routes), avoiding return trips unless necessary.

title: Museum Artifact Transport and Return Logistics
content: A cultural heritage organization loans artifacts between museums. Trucks (<capacity>) from artifact depots (<loc_depot>) first deliver exhibits (linehaul `<demand_linehaul>`) to host museums, then retrieve them post-exhibition (backhaul `<demand_backhaul>`). Museums enforce strict installation/removal time windows (<time_windows>), and routes must originate from the nearest depot but conclude at the final destination (open routes). Capacity constraints ensure fragile items are not overstacked, and backhauls only occur after exhibits are securely displayed.

title: High-Tech Manufacturing Material Logistics
content: A semiconductor manufacturer operates multiple regional depots to supply raw materials (e.g., silicon wafers) to production facilities and collect hazardous chemical waste for recycling. Vehicles must first deliver materials to factories (linehaul) before returning to depots with waste (backhaul). Routes must respect strict production time windows (TW) for assembly lines and ensure vehicle capacities (C) are not exceeded. Depots are strategically located (MD) to serve clusters of factories, optimizing fuel efficiency while avoiding cross-contamination of cleanroom materials with waste during combined routes.

title: Urban Electric Scooter Battery Redistribution Network
content: A city’s electric scooter-sharing service uses decentralized depots (MD) to recharge batteries and redistribute them to high-demand areas during off-peak hours. Empty battery containers (backhaul) are collected from low-usage stations and returned to depots for recharging. Each vehicle (C) must prioritize delivering fully charged batteries (linehaul) to critical zones before collecting depleted ones. Time windows (TW) align with commuter patterns (e.g., rush hour peaks), requiring precise scheduling to meet demand spikes without overloading scooters’ battery compartments.

title: Aerospace Component Delivery and Core Return for Maintenance Hubs
content: An aerospace logistics provider manages multiple depots (MD) supplying replacement parts (linehaul) to aircraft maintenance facilities and retrieving used components (backhaul) for recycling. Routes must ensure critical parts arrive before scheduled maintenance windows (TW) to avoid flight delays. Vehicles (C) must balance weight limits for both new and old components, with backhaul pickups restricted to post-delivery stages. Depots are located near airports to minimize cross-country travel, streamlining global fleet maintenance operations.

title: Cruise Ship Provisions and Waste Retrieval at Port Depots
content: Port logistics managers coordinate deliveries of perishable supplies (e.g., food, fuel) to cruise ships (linehaul) during brief docking windows and organize waste collection (backhaul) from the ships. Each depot (MD) serves specific port terminals, with time windows (TW) synchronized to ship schedules. Vehicles (C) must handle dual cargo types (e.g., chilled groceries and waste bins) without exceeding weight limits, ensuring supplies are offloaded before waste pickup to maintain safety standards.

title: High-Speed Rail Maintenance Parts Deployment and Component Retrieval
content: Railway maintenance crews operate from distributed depots (MD) to deliver spare parts (linehaul) to trackside repair stations during scheduled maintenance windows (TW). Faulty components (backhaul) are retrieved afterward for analysis. Routes must adhere to strict time constraints to minimize service disruptions, with vehicles (C) balancing part delivery loads (e.g., heavy wheelsets) and returning lightweight scrap metal. Open routes (O) allow technicians to end at remote repair sites after completing repairs, avoiding return trips to depots.

title: Urban Garden Supply and Compost Collection Network
content: A network of urban farms and community gardens requires organic fertilizer deliveries from multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`). Simultaneously, these locations generate compostable waste that must be collected for processing. Each garden has a delivery time window `<time_windows>` for fertilizer before planting seasons and a pickup window after harvests. Vehicles departing from depots must first deliver `<demand_linehaul>` tons of fertilizer, then collect `<demand_backhaul>` tons of compost, adhering to capacity limits `<capacity>`. Routes are open-ended, ending at the final collection point to minimize return trips.

title: Maritime Refrigerated Cargo Deployment and Container Retrieval
content: A port authority operates multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deploy refrigerated containers to ships (`<loc_customer>`), ensuring perishable goods are delivered before vessel departure time windows `<time_windows>`. After unloading, empty containers must be retrieved for reuse. Vehicles must first complete deliveries within `<capacity>` ton limits, then collect containers post-departure. Routes are structured to avoid depot returns, optimizing coastal traffic flow and adhering to strict maritime schedules.

title: Airport Maintenance Parts Delivery and废旧部件回收
content: Airport maintenance teams at multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) supply critical spare parts (`<demand_linehaul>`) to aircraft for scheduled inspections. After repairs, used components (`<demand_backhaul>`) are collected for recycling. Time windows `<time_windows>` align with flight schedules, requiring deliveries before maintenance begins and pickups after completion. Vehicles must prioritize part deliveries before backhaul pickups, ensuring capacity `<capacity>` isn’t exceeded during mixed cargo.

title: University Exam Materials Distribution and Answer Sheet Collection
content: A university system uses decentralized depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver exam materials (`<demand_linehaul>`) to campuses `<loc_customer>` before scheduled test windows `<time_windows>`. After exams, answer sheets (`<demand_backhaul>`) are collected for grading. Routes must first distribute materials, then collect sheets, without returning to depots. Capacity `<capacity>` constraints require efficient packing of both fragile exam kits and bulky answer bundles.

title: Holiday Lighting Delivery and Post-Festival Recycling
content: A festive lighting company operates from multiple warehouses (`<loc_depot>`) to distribute holiday lights (`<demand_linehaul>`) to retailers `<loc_customer>` before seasonal deadlines `<time_windows>`. Post-holiday, expired or damaged bulbs (`<demand_backhaul>`) are collected for recycling. Vehicles must first complete deliveries, then pickups, avoiding depot returns. Capacity `<capacity>` limits enforce segregation of new lights (linehaul) and waste (backhaul) to prevent contamination during transport.

title: Adventure Tourism Gear Deployment and Retrieval
content: A network of adventure tour operators uses multiple depots (e.g., mountain bases, coastal hubs, and desert outposts) to supply gear to remote tour sites. Each tour location requires equipment delivery (e.g., kayaks, climbing gear) as linehaul shipments before pickup of used gear (backhaul) at the end of the tour. Tours have strict start times (time windows) to align with weather or tidal conditions. Vehicles must deliver gear first, then collect it, without exceeding weight limits (capacity). Routes are open-ended, terminating at the final tour site to avoid unnecessary return trips.

title: Film Set Equipment Redistribution Across Multiple Studios
content: A film production company operates from multiple depots (e.g., Los Angeles, New York, and Atlanta warehouses) to deploy camera rigs, lighting equipment, and props (linehaul) to filming locations. After shoots conclude, crews must collect gear (backhaul) for reuse. Each filming site has a time window (TW) for setup and teardown, requiring precise scheduling. Vehicles must first deliver equipment before pickups and cannot exceed their payload capacity (C). Routes end at the last site visited, as trucks are repurposed for other tasks post-delivery.

title: School District Furniture Redistribution with Facility Renovations
content: A school district uses regional depots (MD) to deliver new classroom furniture (linehaul) to schools undergoing renovations while collecting outdated desks (backhaul). Schools have time windows (TW) tied to start dates, ensuring furniture arrives before staff arrive. Delivery trucks must prioritize installations before pickups, adhering to capacity limits (C). Routes are open, concluding at the last school to streamline logistics during district-wide transitions.

title: Urban Solar Panel Installation and Recycling Network
content: Solar energy firms deploy teams from multiple depots (MD) to install new panels (linehaul) on rooftops and collect expired panels (backhaul) for recycling. Installations must occur within time windows (TW) to avoid conflicts with building maintenance schedules. Vehicles must first deliver panels before pickups, without exceeding weight capacity (C). Routes terminate at the final site to align with end-of-day recycling plant drop-offs.

title: Trade Show Booth Logistics for Multi-City Events
content: A trade show organizer uses depots in major cities (MD) to transport exhibition booths, signage, and displays (linehaul) to convention centers and collect them post-event (backhaul). Time windows (TW) dictate strict setup and teardown deadlines. Vehicles must first deploy equipment before pickups, ensuring capacity (C) limits are not breached. Routes end at the last event location to optimize truck utilization across simultaneous regional shows.

title: Florist Delivery and Vase Return Network
content: A nationwide florist chain operates from multiple regional depots (`<loc_depot>`) to deliver fresh bouquets to customers (`<loc_customer>`) while collecting returned vases for reuse. Each delivery vehicle (`<capacity> kg`) must first deliver flowers (linehaul) before collecting vases (backhaul). Customers have time windows (`<time_windows>`) for deliveries, ensuring freshness, while vase pickups are scheduled during off-peak hours. Routes must originate from and end at any depot, with open-ended paths to minimize detours.

title: Grocery Home Delivery with Curbside Recycling Pickup
content: A supermarket chain uses `<loc_depot>` distribution centers to send trucks (`<capacity> m³`) to households (`<loc_customer>`) for grocery deliveries (linehaul) and curbside recycling collection (backhaul). Deliveries must occur during customers’ specified time windows (`<time_windows>`), while recycling pickups are timed after trash collection schedules. Vehicles must prioritize deliveries before pickups and ensure capacity constraints aren’t breached, with routes ending at the last stop to reduce idle return trips.

title: Construction Equipment Rental Logistics
content: A construction equipment rental firm operates from `<loc_depot>` warehouses to deploy machinery (`<demand_linehaul>`) to active job sites (`<loc_customer>`) and retrieve returned gear (`<demand_backhaul>`). Time windows (`<time_windows>`) align with contractors’ schedules, requiring precise timing for both deliveries and pickups. Vehicles (`<capacity> ton`) must first deliver equipment before collecting returns, with routes originating from and terminating at any depot to avoid unnecessary backtracking.

title: National Park Trail Signage Deployment and Collection
content: Park rangers manage `<loc_depot>` storage hubs to deploy new trail signs (`<demand_linehaul>`) to remote locations (`<loc_customer>`) and collect outdated ones (`<demand_backhaul>`). Vehicles (`<capacity> kg`) must navigate rugged terrain, adhering to time windows (`<time_windows>`) during which trails are accessible. Routes are open-ended to end at the final trailhead, ensuring efficient use of limited maintenance resources.

title: Movie Production Equipment Redistribution
content: A film production company coordinates `<loc_depot>` equipment warehouses to deliver cameras, lighting, and props (`<demand_linehaul>`) to filming locations (`<loc_customer>`) and retrieve gear from concluded scenes (`<demand_backhaul>`). Time windows (`<time_windows>`) align with tight shooting schedules, requiring vehicles (`<capacity> m³`) to first deliver equipment before collecting returns. Routes originate from any depot and terminate at the final site to meet deadlines while avoiding overtime costs.

title: Urban Vertical Farm Supply and Compost Redistribution
content: A network of urban vertical farms requires nutrient delivery (linehaul) and compost collection (backhaul). Multiple depots are strategically placed across the city to serve clusters of farms. Each farm has strict operating hours (time windows) during which deliveries must occur to avoid disrupting cultivation cycles. Vehicles must first deliver fertilizers and seeds (up to `<capacity>` kg) before returning to collect compost waste. Routes must optimize fuel use while adhering to farm schedules, ensuring no vehicle overloads during either phase.

title: Film Production Drone Logistics with Tight Scheduling
content: A film production company deploys drones for aerial shots to multiple filming locations (`<loc_customer>`) across a region. Each drone delivery (linehaul) must occur within precise time windows tied to scene schedules, while post-shoot drone retrieval (backhaul) must follow immediately after filming concludes. The company uses multi-depot hubs (`<loc_depot>`) to cover diverse filming sites. Drones have limited battery capacity (`<capacity>`), requiring optimized routes to minimize recharging stops.

title: Medical Imaging Equipment Maintenance and Parts Recycling
content: Hospitals scattered across a region require urgent replacement parts for MRI and CT scanners (linehaul deliveries). Simultaneously, outdated equipment must be collected for recycling (backhaul). Each hospital has critical maintenance windows (`<time_windows>`) during non-peak hours. The logistics team operates from multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) to ensure rapid response, with vehicles constrained by `<capacity>` to carry both spare parts and bulky old machinery.

title: Event Tech Rental and Return Logistics with Concurrent Deadlines
content: A tech rental firm supplies audio-visual equipment to simultaneous multi-city festivals (`<loc_customer>`). Rentals (linehaul) must arrive before event starts (`<time_windows>`), while returns (backhaul) must be collected immediately after. The firm uses regional depots (`<loc_depot>`) to minimize travel. Each vehicle (`<capacity>`) must first deliver gear to all assigned locations before backtracking to collect equipment, ensuring no overload during either phase.

title: Maritime Refrigerated Cargo Redistribution with Port Time Constraints
content: A shipping company distributes perishable goods (e.g., seafood, pharmaceuticals) to port terminals (`<loc_customer>`) via refrigerated containers (linehaul) and retrieves empty containers afterward (backhaul). Ports operate on strict schedules (`<time_windows>`) tied to vessel arrivals/departures. Multiple depots (`<loc_depot>`) along the coast enable efficient coverage. Vehicles must prioritize deliveries before pickups, ensuring `<capacity>` constraints on container weight and refrigeration load.

title: Urban Mobility Scooter Redistribution and Battery Retrieval
content: A micro-mobility company operates electric scooters across a city using multiple regional depots (`<loc_depot>`). Each depot dispatches trucks with a `<capacity>` limit to first deliver fully charged scooters to high-demand zones (`<loc_customer>`), then collect depleted units for battery replacement. Scooter deployment locations have strict time windows (`<time_windows>`) to ensure availability during peak hours, while pickups must occur after service hours. The trucks must complete deliveries before initiating collections (backhaul constraint), ensuring no vehicle exceeds its battery and scooter payload limits. Routes end at the final pickup point to avoid empty return trips.

title: High-Tech Semiconductor Component Delivery and Defective Part Retrieval
content: A semiconductor manufacturer uses multiple regional warehouses (`<loc_depot>`) to supply critical components (`<demand_linehaul>`) to assembly lines (`<loc_customer>`), while simultaneously retrieving defective parts (`<demand_backhaul>`) for recycling. Each delivery truck (`<capacity>`) must first deliver components before collecting faulty items, adhering to tight production time windows (`<time_windows>`) to avoid halting manufacturing. Trucks originate and end at their assigned depot but finish routes at the last customer site (open routes), optimizing fleet utilization.

title: Academic Lab Equipment Deployment and Hazardous Waste Collection
content: A university network (`<loc_depot>`) manages lab equipment distribution to multiple research facilities (`<loc_customer>`), requiring precise time windows (`<time_windows>`) for safety protocols. Trucks (`<capacity>`) first deliver specialized gear (e.g., microscopes) and then collect hazardous waste (backhaul). The sequence ensures no contamination risks, with routes terminating at the final waste collection point to reduce idle travel. Multi-depot coordination balances equipment availability across campuses while respecting strict capacity limits.

title: Film Production Gear Distribution and Post-Shoot Equipment Retrieval
content: A film production company coordinates equipment logistics for multi-location shoots using regional equipment hubs (`<loc_depot>`). Trucks (`<capacity>`) must first deliver lighting rigs, cameras, and props (`<demand_linehaul>`) to film sets (`<loc_customer>`) within strict filming time windows (`<time_windows>`), then collect gear after scenes are wrapped (backhaul). Routes are designed to end at the last retrieval site (open routes), optimizing truck utilization for concurrent film schedules across multiple cities.

title: Offshore Wind Farm Maintenance Parts Delivery and废旧部件回收 with Time Windows
content: Wind farm operators must deliver repair kits to turbines (linehaul) and collect废旧components for recycling (backhaul). Multiple offshore service bases act as depots (MD). title: Film Set Drone Logistics with Concurrent Shooting Deadlines
content: A film production company deploys drones (linehaul) to multiple filming locations (MD) for aerial shots and retrieves them afterward (backhaul). Each drone has a battery capacity (C) limiting flight duration. Locations must be serviced within strict shooting time windows (TW), with routes ending at the final scene (O). Simultaneously, drones must avoid overlapping schedules to prevent airspace conflicts.

title: High-Speed Rail Maintenance Parts Redistribution with Scheduled Downtime
content: Railway operators use regional depots (MD) to deliver replacement parts (linehaul) to trackside stations and collect废旧equipment (backhaul). Maintenance windows (TW) are synchronized with train schedules, requiring precise timing. Maintenance trucks (C) must complete routes without returning to depots (O), optimizing paths across multiple rail segments.

title: Urban Vertical Farm Hydroponic Supply and废旧Nutrient Recycling
content: A network of urban farms (MD) requires nutrient solutions (linehaul) to be delivered to rooftop greenhouses and废旧packaging retrieved (backhaul). Deliveries must align with farmers’ operating hours (TW), while trucks (C) avoid overloading. Routes terminate at the last farm (O), streamlining logistics for perishable crops.

title: Cruise Ship Provisions Delivery and Waste Retrieval at Port Depots
content: Ports act as multi-depots (MD) to supply perishable goods (linehaul) to arriving cruise ships and collect food waste (backhaul) for recycling. Each ship’s docking schedule defines time windows (TW), and port trucks (C) must optimize routes without returning to depots (O). Capacity constraints ensure fresh provisions are prioritized during limited loading times.
